qas.question: How many people were killed in the Hanshin earthquake?
How did Yuji Yagi say the quake happened?
What fault tore in two places?
Besides the population density, what else contributed to the severity of the quake?
How much greater was the energy of this quake than that released in the earthquake of 1995 in Japan?
Why did the seismic waves travel so far?

context: Japanese seismologist Yuji Yagi at the University of Tsukuba said that the earthquake occurred <a1_0>in two stages<a1_0/>: "The 155-mile <a2_0>Longmenshan Fault<a2_0/> tore in two sections, the first one ripping about seven yards, followed by a second one that sheared four yards." His data also showed that the earthquake lasted about two minutes and released <a4_0>30 times<a4_0/> the energy of the Great Hanshin earthquake of 1995 in Japan, which killed over <a0_0>6,000 people<a0_0/>. He pointed out that the <a3_0>shallowness of the epicenter<a3_0/> and the density of population greatly increased the severity of the earthquake. Teruyuki Kato, a seismologist at the University of Tokyo, said that the seismic waves of the quake traveled a long distance without losing their power because of the <a5_0>firmness of the terrain<a5_0/> in central China. According to reports from Chengdu, the capital of Sichuan province, the earthquake tremors lasted for "about two or three minutes".
